import plotly.graph_objects as go
import plotly.offline as py
import plotly.graph_objs as go

import matplotlib

import warnings

#Code by Baekhakjeon https://www.kaggle.com/baekhakjeon/explorer-tabular-playground-series-apr-2021

plt.figure(figsize = (10, 5), dpi = 100)
ax = sns.countplot(x='category', hue='yrcompiled', palette= ["Chartreuse", "magenta", "teal", "crimson", "black", "purple"], data=df)

# Display values on the plot
for p in ax.patches:
    ax.annotate(text=p.get_height(), xy=(p.get_x()+0.2, p.get_height()+1000), horizontalalignment='center', verticalalignment='top', color='black', size=10)

plt.title("Reptile Species Category by Year of Compilation", fontsize=20)    
plt.xlabel('Categories', fontsize=15)
plt.ylabel('Counts', fontsize=15)
#plt.legend(['Not Extinct', 'Extinct'], fontsize=15)
plt.show()

plt.figure(figsize = (10, 5), dpi = 100)
ax = sns.countplot(x='order_', hue='yrcompiled', palette= ["orange", "teal"], data=df)

# Display values on the plot
for p in ax.patches:
    ax.annotate(text=p.get_height(), xy=(p.get_x()+0.2, p.get_height()+1000), horizontalalignment='center', verticalalignment='top', color='black', size=10)

plt.ylabel('Counts', fontsize=15)
plt.legend(['testudines', 'crocodylia'], fontsize=15) #whithout hue the legend showed only testudines
plt.show()
source.1d6358ce:
#word cloud
from wordcloud import WordCloud, ImageColorGenerator
text = " ".join(str(each) for each in df.binomial)
# Create and generate a word cloud image:
wordcloud = WordCloud(max_words=200,colormap='Set3', background_color="black").generate(text)
plt.figure(figsize=(10,6))
plt.figure(figsize=(15,10))
# Display the generated image:
plt.imshow(wordcloud, interpolation='Bilinear')
plt.axis("off")
plt.figure(1,figsize=(12, 12))
plt.show()
source.22acb0ee:
text_cols = ['compiler', 'kingdom', 'phylum', 'citation']

from wordcloud import WordCloud, STOPWORDS

wc = WordCloud(stopwords = set(list(STOPWORDS) + ['|']), random_state = 42)
fig, axes = plt.subplots(2, 2, figsize=(20, 12))
axes = [ax for axes_row in axes for ax in axes_row]

for i, c in enumerate(text_cols):
  op = wc.generate(str(df[c]))
  _ = axes[i].imshow(op)
  _ = axes[i].set_title(c.upper(), fontsize=24)
  _ = axes[i].axis('off')

source.330376a6:
#Codes by Alexander Filin https://www.kaggle.com/infamous25700/pornactors-are-among-us-18

from pywaffle import Waffle

compiler = df["compiler"].value_counts()

plt.figure(
    FigureClass=Waffle,
    rows=5,
    columns=10,
    values=compiler,
    title={'label': 'Compiler Distribution', 'loc': 'left'},
    labels=["{}({})".format(a, b) for a, b in zip(compiler.index, compiler) ],
    # Set the position of the legend
    legend={'loc': 'upper left', 'bbox_to_anchor': (1, 1)},
    dpi=100,    
    figsize=(12, 8), #Re-size to avoid Tight layout not applied. The left and right margins cannot be made large
    colors = ["#ffa31a", "#D17200", "#9c5400", "#763f00", "#422400", "#a88732"]
)
plt.show()
source.51181888:
existence = df["legend"].value_counts()

plt.figure(
    FigureClass=Waffle,
    rows=5,
    columns=10,
    values=existence,
    figsize=(12, 8),  #added to avoid Tight layout not applied. The left and right margins cannot be made large
    title={'label': 'Existence Distribution', 'loc': 'left'},
    labels=["{}({})".format(a, b) for a, b in zip(existence.index, existence) ],
    # Set the position of the legend
    legend={'loc': 'upper left', 'bbox_to_anchor': (1, 1)},
    dpi=100
)
plt.show()

source.51450ced:
Taxonomic Ranks


There are seven main taxonomic ranks: Kingdom, Phylum or division, Class, Order, Family, Genus, Species. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Taxonomic_rank
source.377ef79d:
Reptiles Taxonomy


"Taxonomy is the practice and science of categorization or classification. The word finds its roots in the Greek language τάξις, taxis (meaning 'order', 'arrangement') and νόμος, nomos ('law' or 'science'). "A taxonomy (or taxonomical classification) is a scheme of classification, especially a hierarchical classification, in which things are organized into groups or types. Among other things, a taxonomy can be used to organize and index knowledge (stored as documents, articles, videos, etc.), such as in the form of a library classification system, or a search engine taxonomy, so that users can more easily find the information they are searching for. Many taxonomies are hierarchies (and thus, have an intrinsic tree structure), but not all are." https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Taxonomy

source.6917ebcd:
#The IUCN Red List 

"Established in 1964, The International Union for Conservation of Nature’s Red List of Threatened Species has evolved to become the world’s most comprehensive information source on the global conservation status of animal, fungi and plant species."

"The IUCN Red List is a critical indicator of the health of the world’s biodiversity. Far more than a list of species and their status, it is a powerful tool to inform and catalyze action for biodiversity conservation and policy change, critical to protecting the natural resources we need to survive. It provides information about range, population size, habitat and ecology, use and/or trade, threats, and conservation actions that will help inform necessary conservation decisions."

https://www.iucnredlist.org/

https://www.iucnredlist.org/resources/files/4591738e-2d0c-4fc0-b4de-5413ec5bab26  Data source
source.817bc292:
Reptiles Species Categories


Reptiles species are categorized according to the IUCN Red List criteria. "The IUCN Red List Categories and Criteria are intended to be an easily and widely understood system for classifying species at high risk of global extinction. It divides species into nine categories: Not Evaluated, Data Deficient, Least Concern, Near Threatened, Vulnerable, Endangered, Critically Endangered, Extinct in the Wild and Extinct." Critically Endangered (CR), Endangered (EN), Vulnerable (VU), Near Threatened (NT), Data Deficient (DD) Least Concern (LC). Extinct in the Wild. Extinct. The paper below didn't mention what is LR/nt, LR/lc and LR/cd https://www.scielo.br/j/isz/a/QLvH7XNwC84skbhLCsxmsbn/?lang=en&format=pdf The IUCN Red List of Threatened Species https://www.iucnredlist.org/
